properties.name: Exeter, Fore st between broadgate and Milk Lane
properties.description: 55 Alexandrian coins among approx 1110 reported coins altogether, including 9 Ptolemaic, 35 Syrian., 11 Byzantine.
properties.context: found by workmen digging high street - unknown context. Sewer in Fore Street, 20 ft deep. Between Broadgate and Milk Lane.

properties.name: Exeter, St George's Church
properties.description: 1 Ptolemaic, 5(?) Alexandrian (Trajan 1, Diocletian Y3, Aurelian, Claudius II 269AD, 2 x Philip I Y3 & Y6?), 3 Syrian, 2 Byzantine
properties.context: Coins in posession of Mr. Jos. Gard. found duringe excavations above St George's Church. Not clear that they were found together (especially with Byzantine coins). Found during removal of Southgate

properties.name: Poltimore
properties.description: 3 Ptolemaic, 4 (2?) Alexandrian (1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius; 1 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), 10 Syrian, 3 Byzantine.
properties.context: hoard of Greek and Egyptian coins found an a spot in Poltimore by a farmour labouring in a field and separate finds in same field. Found at various times in fields around Poltimore

properties.name: Carbeile
properties.description: A coin of Ptolemy IV (BC 221 - 205) found in ploughing Mr. Reynold's farm, Carbeile (SX 4355). Presented to Plymouth Museum.

properties.name: Truro, Highertown
properties.description: presented to Royal Institution of Cornwall. Dug up in farm garden

properties.name: Westhill
properties.description: Found on West Hill (SY 0793) near Aylesbeare Common.
properties.context: The finder, who retained the coin, would not give the exact location, but said that the coin was found about two feet below the surface on a building site where no building work had previously taken place. The coin, which was in fair condition, had on the obverse the head of Zeus, and on the reverse, an eagle standing upon a thunderbolt. the coin would appear to be a genuine archaeological find rather than a chance recent loss, and takes its place with the two Greek silver coins found at Holne (SX 76 NW 3,5) which demonstrated South Wstern connections with the Mediterranean in the Early Iron Age. (1)
